Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Electron Acceleration and Emissions from the Solar Flare Termination Shock
Award.AbstractNarration:
This collaborative research project plans to make significant progress toward our understanding of one of the key problems in solar physics; i.e., the question of how electrons are accelerated within solar flares. Solar flares are the strongest explosions in the Solar System, and they provide sites for particle acceleration and high-energy emission. However, the question of exactly how this acceleration occurs remains unsolved. The project will combine two powerful numerical models that will enable the principal investigators (PIs) to simulate the physics over a wide range of scales from the large scale flares that produce shock waves down to the smallest scales where the particle acceleration occurs. This project will also support the training of the next generation of solar scientists. The PIs will involve both undergraduate and graduate students in the research, and funding is provided for a postdoctoral researcher for the project.

In solar flares, a termination shock can develop when a high-speed outflow from the flare encounters magnetic loops in the solar atmosphere forming a standing shock wave that can accelerate particles to high energies. These shock waves had been predicted but never observed until recent X-ray and radio observations by one of the PIs (Chen). Motivated by this recent discovery, this project plans to investigate the dynamical evolution of termination shocks and their acceleration of electrons by combining, for the first time, two powerful numerical simulations: (1) large-scale magnetohydrodynamic (MHD) models of the dynamical evolution of a flare and (2) particle-in-cell kinetic and test-particle simulations for electron acceleration at the shock front. From the combined numerical model the PIs plan to generate synthetic hard X-ray emission and compare this emission with observations.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This NSF-funded project "Collaborative Research: Electron Acceleration and Emissions from the Solar Flare Termination Shock" aims to understand electron acceleration and emission by a type of shocks in solar flares known as the "termination shocks". These shocks are formed by high-speed plasma outflows emanating from the flare energy release site impinging upon the bright flare arcade. While these shocks have long been postulated as one of the main candidates as a particle accelerator in solar flares, compared to other candidate mechanisms, this scenario has received relatively limited attention. This is mainly because the observations and the related modeling studies have been lacking. Motivated by recent observations of solar flare termination shocks, in this project, we investigated the dynamical evolution of the termination shocks and the associated electron acceleration by combining novel imaging spectroscopy observations and state-of-the-art numerical simulations. 

The combined observation-modeling approach led to unprecedented understanding of termination shocks in solar flares. Using ultra-high cadence radio imaging spectroscopy observations obtained by NSF's Jansky Very Large Array (VLA), we reported a "split-band" feature in the frequency domain, interpreted as plasma radiation from the upstream and downstream sides of the shock. With these observations, we have, for the first time, derived the spatially and temporally resolved shock compression ratio and Mach number along the shock front (Chen et al. 2019, The Astrophysical Journal), which compared favorably with numerical simulation results (Shen et al. 2018, The Astrophysical Journal). In another work, using newly available microwave imaging spectroscopy observations, we reported a "magnetic bottle" at the top of the solar flare arcade (Chen et al. 2020, Nature Astronomy), which may be favorable for confining charged particles in the vicinity of the termination shock for repeated energization (Kong et al. 2019, The Astrophysical Journal Letters). Using magnetohydrodynamics and large-scale particle simulations, we demonstrated that the arrival of plasmoids (closed, small-scale magnetic structures) at the shock front can modulate the acceleration processes (Kong et al. 2020, The Astrophysical Journal Letters), a phenomenon reported by an earlier observational study (Chen et al. 2015, Science). Such a modulation of accelerated electrons in response to plasma flows was also reported in our observations using microwave imaging spectroscopy data made by the NSF-funded Expanded Owens Valley Solar Array (Yu et al. 2020, The Astrophysical Journal).

The project provided partial funding support, training, and professional development to postdoctoral fellow Dr. Sijie Yu, who was promoted to Assistant Research Professor in August 2020. PI Chen and Dr. Yu published their results in peer-reviewed publications and disseminated them at several conferences and workshops. The project also supported the work by graduate student Mr. Yingjie Luo under PI Chen's supervision. This work, which was submitted to The Astrophysical Journal, constitutes a major part of Mr. Luo's Ph.D. thesis project. The work supported by this project received wide attention in the community, which includes a news story issued by NSF, an article in the Astronomy Magazine, and science highlights by RHESSI and CESRA. In addition, results related to this project were disseminated to the general public by PI Chen in a number of public lectures given to local astronomy clubs in New Jersey and New York.
